instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message: Hello I checked <CHIP>U9310</CHIP> all the output voltages are 0V I only get 1.5V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SSD_LIM</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message:
Do you get correct voltages and signals on both sides of J9600?
Check continuity left/right.

What about <SIGNAL>SSD_PWRCON0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SSD_PMIC_LDO</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U9310</CHIP>).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message: I solved it by replacing <CAPACITOR>C9301</CAPACITOR>, now I have a problem with the audio it does not emit sound, except that of charging, it does not emit the boot sound and the sound in general, the system detects the internal speakers

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message:
The machine detects the headphones?
Did you try another speakers?

Check RESET* signal of all audio amplifiers.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message: Now the image is disturbed in this way[ATTACH type="full"]61133[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message:
Did you try known good screen?
What about external monitor?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message: Tried with a new screen and it does the same, it looks like a logic board problem

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question folder
threads.message:
Can you switch between iGPU and dGPU and see if image changes?

"What about external monitor?"
dGPU is enabled then.
